title: Hammond back with Senators, ahead of schedule | Hockey | Sports Sun
text:
COLUMBUS - Not only has Andrew Hammond made an early return to the Senators lineup, but expect him to start Thursday night in Pittsburgh.
At least that’s what we deduced from the reply coach Dave Cameron had when asked if “The Hamburglar” would be used on the two-game road trip that begins Wednesday at Nationwide Arena.
“He’s certainly in the mix,” said Cameron. “We’ve got back to back games so yeah, he’ll probably get a game somewhere.”
That means Hammond would face the Penguins, unless Cameron dares to staple his No. 1 goalie, Craig Anderson, to the bench for a second straight game when the Senators square off against the Blue Jackets Wednesday.
Anderson would not like that one bit, as he already isn’t too happy about sitting out the home opener last Sunday.
“I was told to be ready to go, then in the morning I was told I wasn’t playing,” said Anderson, who posted a shootout victory over the Leafs in the Senators’ first of last weekend’s back-to-backers. “So I don’t think they had a decision made on Saturday night, they just mentioned to be ready and they made the decision on Sunday.”
To be clear, Anderson didn’t publicly criticize the call. Only his body language agreed with what others were thinking: How could you not use your No. 1 goalie in the first game at Canadian Tire Centre of the season, especially when it was against the division rival Montreal Canadiens?
What Anderson actually said sounded a lot like the words that came from Blue Jays knuckleballer R.A. Dickey after he was pulled when going good in Game 4 of the American League Division Series.
“I had no part of the decision,” said Anderson, who is out of the gate with a 2-0 start and has played countless back-to-back games in his career. “I’m the player, and my job is to be ready to play, when I’m told to play. I’m not the guy ... as a player you don’t dictate when or how you play. It’s coach’s decision.”
But disappointing not to be a part of the home opener nonetheless?
“I was still part of it. I was still getting out there ... getting the double wave going,” cracked Anderson. “I think it was just kind of the nature of the schedule, and coach’s decision. I was there to support my teammates, and make sure I could do everything I could to help the team win, in the situation I was in.”
The return of Hammond from the first groin injury of his career has, as expected, resulted in Matt O’Connor’s demotion to Binghamton. Like everyone else, Anderson praised O’Connor for his debut performance, which saw the rookie allow a soft first period goal but winding up with 31 saves.
Cameron, who said O’Connor “was not the issue” in the 3-1 loss, is now demanding better back zone play from his team.
“More aggressive defensively in our own end, is the biggest thing we have to do,” said Cameron. “We’re too passive in our own end.”
Hammond was supposed to be out for two weeks, so he’s beating that timeline by a couple of days. After “four or five” on-ice workouts, he finally practised with his teammates Tuesday.
“I feel ready,” said Hammond, who has a 20-1-2 regular season record as a starter in the NHL. “I feel comfortable. (There’s) nothing (in the way of lingering pain). That was part of the deal ... if there’s anything at all, to shut it down, because that’s really how these things kind of become something that will carry on throughout the season.
“If it would have been last year, the end of the season and the playoffs or something, I don’t think I would have taken any time off. But it was something that was only going to get worse, so it’s just something you’ve got to kind of nip in the bud now.”
The Senators will bring a 13-0-3 road record (dating back to last season) into a battle with a Blue Jackets team that has had trouble getting untracked this season.
Their 0-3-0 mark is comprised of a home-opening 4-2 loss to the New York Rangers, a 5-2 defeat at the hands of those same Blueshirts at Madison Square Garden, and a 4-2 fumble in Buffalo.
With high expectations placed on them this season, Columbus players used the words “disappointing” and “unacceptable” regarding the loss to the rebuilding Sabres, while coach Todd Richards said it was “concerning.”
As a result, the Senators will be treading into dangerous waters.
“They’ll be pressing,” said winger Clarke MacArthur. “They’re going to do a little extra to get that first win. Anytime you get 0-3, even though it’s early, they’re going to be making plays, pushing and trying to get something done early.
“We’ve got to be aware of that early on. It’s a tough building to play in. We’ve got to be ready for them.”

Hammond back with Senators, ahead of schedule
By Don Brennan , Ottawa Sun First posted: Tuesday, October 13, 2015 12:20 PM EDT | Updated: Tuesday, October 13, 2015 08:11 PM EDT
The Senators did some goalie shuffling before heading off to Columbus Tuesday afternoon.
Andrew Hammond was declared good to return from a groin injury that had sidelined him for the start of the season, meaning rookie Matt O’Connor was sent to the AHL affiliate in Binghamton.
Craig Anderson is expected to get the start Wednesday, when the 2-1-0 Senators take on the Blue Jackets at Nationwide Arena.
Hammond, who led Ottawa to the playoffs last spring, said he’s been skating by himself for the last four or five days.
